Current Status: Most of the houses were demolished or moved in the 1950s. The old Co-op remains and still bears the town name. Large berm south of the co-op is what is left from the demolition 38.174742,-98.962701
Townsite was abandoned, only ruins remain
Remarks: Was a health resort that lasted into the 1930s.

Current Status: Still on maps but little remains
Remarks: A trading post was established on the site in 1852
Was actually a trading post from 1826-1828

Current Status: A Kansas River access point is near the location and named after the town.
Remarks: Was a Lecompton satellite community.

Current Status: A Kansas State Historical Marker is near the location along U.S. 59.
Remarks: Location of the Battle of Hickory Point, a skirmish between pro-slavery and free state forces.

Current Status: A small population resides along K-116.
A couple buildings and a cemetery remain
On private property and not accessible
The old territorial capitol building still stands is well-preserved
Remarks: Was the territorial capitol until 1855 when it was moved to Shawnee Mission.
Moved two miles west when Tuttle Creek Lake was built.

Current Status: Located on Corps land and is easily accessible.
Remarks: Abandoned for the construction of Tuttle Creek Lake.
Was never an official town but was a stop on the Oregon Trail. Numerous carvings in the spring's rocks feature traveler's initials and other things. A member of the Donner Party is buried nearby.

Current Status: A small population remains just off of U.S. 69.
Remarks: Near the site of the Marais des Cygnes massacre.

Current Status: A small population remains on a county road about ten miles northwest of Ottawa Centropolis Christian Church and Centropolis Baptist Church are open.

Remarks: Was the territorial capitol briefly in 1858. Not to be confused with Minneola in Clark County.

Current Status: Several buildings remain including an old house and a stone school southwest of Williamsburg.
Santa Fe Trail wagon swales, a roadside park, cemetery and the well-preserved battlefield site remain and are open to public.
Nothing remains of the town except two small neglected cemeteries and Franklin Road off of K-10.
A small population remains along U.S. 40.

Remarks: Calhoun was also the name of a county that was made up of northern Shawnee County, most of Jackson County and half of Pottawatomie County. When Shawnee County's northern border was extended, Calhoun ceased to be.
There is an Indianola Road located near the Goodyear Plant near U.S. 24.

Current Status: Was mainly a paper town that was supposed to be an all-black community east of Topeka.
Townsite is now located in and around the Green Wildlife Refuge southeast of Willard.
Remarks: Uniontown was a trail stop and a place where the Pottawatomi would spend money. A cholera epidemic killed 22 Indians and they were buried in a mass grave. The grave is located in the center of the cemetery. Not to be confused with Uniontown in Bourbon County.

Current Status: There is still a small population in the area.

Remarks: Several ruins of the downtown and old consolidated school remain.

Current Status: Several buildings remain abandoned in the area.
Remarks: Located about ten miles southwest of Alma.

Current Status: A small population and a huge Catholic church remain three miles north of Paxico.
Any remains of Army City are currently on Fort Riley property.
Remarks: Army City was built exclusively for servicemen at Fort Riley during World War I.

Current Status: Few remains exist but a monument to Diamond Springs was erected in Diamond Springs Cemetery
Any remains are currently maintained by Galena.
Remarks: Empire City was annexed to Galena in 1907.
Ella Wilson was the founder of the town and when she died in 1913, the town died with her.
Was the site of a mass lynching in May 1870.
Octagon City was a social experiment where the settlers of the town vowed to eat no meat. The town was so called because the main streets were laid out in an octagon.

Current Status: The site of Cofachiqui was demolished when a cement company bought the land.
Townsite is now on private property and inaccessible.
A few ruins and structures still survive.

Remarks: Cave Springs was established as a \health\" resort. The resort failed in the 1880s when people starting questioning the springs' healing properties. The town was officially vacated in 1949."

Current Status: Townsite is now on private property.
Townsite is on private property but the Kansas Turnpike does pass under Oil Hill Road just outside of El Dorado.
Some houses and foundations remain along with a cemetery.
The site lies under the waters of Waconda Reservoir.
Remarks: Located near the Waconda Springs, a natural aquifer used by Native Americans.

Current Status: A church, some houses and a cemetery remain.
A small community still exists near the Webster Lake dam.

Remarks: The population was once near 2,000 in 1870s but after the turn of the century, the population began to decline. The city was also the site of the Brookville Hotel until 2000 when the hotel moved to Abilene.

Current Status: The townsite is now located within the city limits of Lindsborg.
Townsite is now on private property.
A beautiful Catholic church and cemetery are all that remain.
A marker near Fort Hays State College indicates where Rome once was.
Remarks: Rome was co-founded by William \Buffalo Bill\" Cody."

Current Status: Townsite is now on private property.

Remarks: Freeport is the smallest incorporated town in Kansas.

Current Status: Old roads and some structures still remain.

Remarks: Achilles was the site of the Battle of Sappa Creek in 1875, it was one of the bloodiest Indian battles fought in northwest Kansas.

Current Status: A railroad town, founded in 1889. The property fell into private hands and was plowed under.
The townsite become the private property of Pat Reilly, who plowed it under, until 1972 when it was sold to the Brown brothers.
Nothing remains of the townsite and is now on private property.

Remarks: The site of Blufton is the same as Threshing Machine Canyon which is part of Cedar Bluff State Park which is a part of the Cedar Bluff Reservoir.

Current Status: A small population exists and several buildings remain.
Nothing remains but some older buildings in Leoti are from Coronado.
Nothing remains of the townsite except a community building.

Remarks: Beersheba was established as an experimental Jewish agricultural community.
Battled with Eminence for county seat of Garfield County. In 1893, Garfield County was annexed to Finney County and the feud was over.
Battled with Ravanna for county seat of Garfield County, which ended in 1893 when Garfield County was annexed to Finney County.

Current Status: The old Ulysses townsite is currently on private property but the \new\" Ulysses site has an estimated population of 5
column7: In 1908, Ulysses moved three miles down the road to a new location in an attempt to not pay back bonds that had become due.

Current Status: Nothing remains and a portion of the townsite is on private property.
Springfield was located at the intersection of U.S. 83 and U.S. 160 north of Liberal.
A small population still remains eight miles southeast of Troy near the Missouri River.
A small community remains along K-20.
A small population remains in the area.
Bain City was annexed to Leavenworth in 1964.
Any remains of Quindaro are now in the city limits of Kansas City in Quindaro Park.

Remarks: Six-Mile House, so called because of its distance from Wyandotte (Kansas City) on Leavenworth Rd, was the headquarters of the Free-State 'Redlegs' who guarded the border of Kansas from pro-slave incursions.

Current Status: Padonia lies among a cluster of houses and farm fields.
Remarks: Padonia was the site of a bloodless skirmish in the 1850s called the Battle of Padonia.

Current Status: The cemetery, church, town hall and schoolhouse have all been restored and well-kept.
St. Columbkillane Catholic Church and former Catholic School still stand at the intersection of K-99 and K-116.
A small cemetery and church mark the townsite.
All that remains is the Antioch Cemetery.
Remarks: Bigelow was demolished during construction of Tuttle Creek Lake.

Current Status: Fort Riley has now expanded into what was Bala.
The old school house,cemertery,and a few houses from the 1940s remain south of Shawnee Mission Parkway in west Shawnee Shawnee and Lenexa.
A small population remains just south of Clinton Lake near Lone Star Lake.
Remarks: A community existed in the area before Lone Star was organized. A post office was formed in 1875 under Bond, then Gideon. The name Lone Star was chosen in the 1890s.

Current Status: The site is well-preserved off of SW 6th Avenue in Topeka and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
Remarks: Potwin was annexed to Topeka in 1899.

Current Status: Auburndale is currently a neighborhood in Topeka and is commemorated by Auburndale Park.
Nothing remains of the townsite except some ruins and the cemetery.
Remarks: Richland is notable for being the birthplace of Georgia Neese Clark, the Treasurer of the United States under President Truman from 1949-1953.

Current Status: Nothing remains of the townsite, it is on private property. A Santa Fe Trail marker marks the general location along U.S. 56.
Some old buildings, ruins and a church still stand in the area.
\Old\" Strawn is now located underneath the John Redmond Reservoir while New Strawn is located along U.S. 75."
A small population and some abandoned businesses remain in the area.
A small population (approx. 20) remains in the area.

Remarks: In 1905, most cabins were burned down. Frank Cotton discovered that the boards on his house were soaked with kerosene. Cotton saved his house but the remaining cabins burned to the ground.

Current Status: Nothing remains of the townsite except Delos Johnson's (the town founder) house and a neglected cemetery.

The Cato Historical Preservation Association meets at 6:30 pm on the fourth Tuesday of each month at Arcadia Community Center, Arcadia, Kansas. The old school has been restored. Cato Christian Church is in good repair, but closed. A community reunion is held yearly.|
A small population remains in the area.
Remarks: Farlington is located just southwest of Crawford State Park on K-7.

Current Status: A small population remains along with some shotgun houses and some building ruins.
Very little remains of the townsite.
2010 Census population of 138. As of May 2012, only 2 people remain.
Remarks: Due to years of mining in the area, the land in and around Treece is unstable and contaminated which had led to the citizens wanting the government to buy their land so that they can move.

Current Status: Some ruins remain east of the Elk City Lake.
Remarks: The town was fairly bustling thanks to a central cement factory in the center of town being the biggest employer. During the Great Depression, cement sales dropped significantly and went out of business, so the town died
Votaw was an experimental colony founded by African-Americans. After 1900, the population slowly moved elsewhere. The last building burned down in 1915.
Boston was the county seat of Howard County which was split into Chautauqua and Elk Counties in 1875. Sedan became the new county seat of Chautauqua County.

Current Status: Currently on property known as the Kalida Farm.
Only a hotel remains that is being used as a residence.
Some structures still remain. A transmission shop is open.

Remarks: A plaque was dedicated in 1990 commemorating Strawberry.

Current Status: A church, now used as a town hall, and a few houses, is all that remains.
A few buildings and population remain.

Remarks: A monument was erected in 1936. Abram was the first Lincoln County Seat.

Current Status: A small population remains just north of Mushroom Rock State Park.

Remarks: Was originally a part of Fort Zarah which was abandoned in 1869. The last resident left Zarah in 1875.

Current Status: Some abandoned buildings and ruins remain.

Remarks: All of Hitschmann is currently on private property.
Frederick is the second-smallest incorporated town in Kansas.

Current Status: Some ruins of the old cement company remain as do some abandoned houses and other buildings.

Remarks: Bluff City was originally founded as a fraud in 1873 to swindle money from the Kansas legislature. The first settlers in the area didn't arrive until 1876.

Disestablished: Post office moved to Manchester, Oklahoma in 1903.
Remarks: Originally named Cameron until 1900.

Current Status: Little remains of old Clear Water but Clearwater has an estimated (as of 2008) population of 2,405.

Remarks: The entire town of Marshall was moved to Cheney in 1883.

Current Status: A small population (approx. 20) remains as well as some houses and other buildings.
A few homes and abandoned buildings remain.
Remarks: Castleton was used as the setting of Sevillinois for the 1952 movie Wait Till the Sun Shines, Nellie.

Current Status: An old schoolhouse, church, and abandoned grocery store remain but most of Lerado is now farmland.

Remarks: Old Kiowa was abandoned when the railroad was built four miles to the south and a new Kiowa was established.

Current Status: A small population (approx. 30) remains. The United Methodist Church is open.
A small resident population of about 40 remains.
Some ruins and abandoned buildings remain.
Remarks: The site of Kanona is currently on private property.

Current Status: A small resident population remains along with some ruins and abandoned buildings.

Remarks: The entire was moved in 1887 to Goodland.

Current Status: A small population remains along U.S. 50.
A small population and some abandoned buildings and ruins still remain.

Remarks: Battled with Hugoton for county seat of Stevens County.

Current Status: Nothing remains of the townsite but the Pardee Cemetery.
Remarks: Named for Pardee Butler, a farmer and preacher who was sent adrift on a raft in the Missouri River by pro-slavery men.

Current Status: Nothing remains of the old fort.
Remarks: Cavagnial is an old French fort and trading post. When Lewis and Clark came through the area in 1804, they saw no sign of the old fort. The exact location is unknown.

Current Status: Some ruins and street grades are all that remain.
The Kansas City Metro area has grown into the area of Springdale.
Nothing remains of the site and it is rumored that it is now under the waters of Perry Lake.
Remarks: Owl City was mainly a section house on the Leavenworth and Topeka Railroad.

Current Status: Some ruins and abandoned building remain on what used to be Main Street.

Remarks: Guittard Station was a major stop for the Pony Express.

Current Status: A small population remains as does some buildings.
The townsite is under the waters of the Tuttle Creek Reservoir.

Remarks: Originally called Big Timber until 1878.

Current Status: Nothing remains but Aubry Township is named for the town.
Remarks: Aubry was located around 192nd Street and Metcalf.
Not to be confused with Oxford, Kansas in Sumner County, an existing city with a population of 1,049 as of 2010.

Current Status: Old residences, streets and other buildings remain in and around Clearview City.
Remarks: Sunflower Village was established exclusively for the Sunflower Army Ammunition Plant, the plant and town remain just off of K-10 south of DeSoto.
William Quantrill lived in Stanton during the winter of 1859-60.

Current Status: The Ransom house still stands as does some other houses and buildings.
A small population remains and Peoria Township is named for it.
A couple of churches, some houses and the old schoolhouse remain.
Remarks: Originally called Deer Creek Community until 1899 when the post office opened, the post office closed in 1903.

Current Status: A small population remains on the north edge of the John Redmond Reservoir.
Ruins of the Havana Stage Station and hotel remain and a sign has been posted on the site.
Remarks: Not to be confused with Havana in Montgomery County.

Current Status: The site is now part of Superior Game Farms just south of Burlingame.
Nothing remains of the townsite, only Rochester Cemetery and Rochester Road in North Topeka mark the site.
Nothing remains of the townsite however Wanamaker Road, Topeka's main western edge road, bears its name.
Remarks: After a tornado destroyed the town in 1917, it was not rebuilt.
The site is currently maintained as a hiking trail by a local chapter of Boy Scouts.

Current Status: The site of Alida lies underneath the waters of Milford Lake.
Only a small cemetery marks the townsite.
Remarks: Was the county seat of Lyon County until losing to Americus who then lost it to Emporia.
Founded by Thomas Lovewell. Most of the town lies under the water of the Lovewell Reservoir.
An Old Dutch Mill, built in 1882, was moved to Smith Center in 1938.

Current Status: A small population remains as well as the ruins of Main Street and a high school gymnasium.
Remarks: Harlan was home to Gould College which lasted from 1881 until 1891.

Current Status: Nothing remains of the townsite except an old well.
Nothing remains of the townsite except for a church & the old Lyona School built in 1870.
Boomer City was established as a town to house the construction people working on the Kanapolis Reservoir. When the lake was completed, the town was abandoned.
The town barely got started and was abandoned soon after its founding.
The town was surveyed but soon after a local child died after arrived in Buchanan, the town was abandoned.
An old blacksmith shop still stands but nothing else remains.

Remarks: Ironically, in 1901, a railroad built a depot at Terra Cotta despite nothing being there. It was moved in 1934.

Current Status: The Idavale Ranch is located on the Kanapolis Reservoir Legacy Trail, along with Terra Cotta.
A small population and building ruins remain.
After the founder, Roger Cain, died, the town was slowly abandoned. Nothing remains of the townsite.
An old grain elevator and a couple of houses remain.
The town never actually existed despite being named the county seat in 1871.
A small population (approx. 20) remains along with a dam built in 1882.
Nothing remains of the townsite, the town was wiped off the map by a tornado.
Coyote was the western terminus of the Union Pacific during construction. When the railroad moved on, Coyote was abandoned.
In 1910, the people of Sherlock renamed the town Holcomb, which still exists.
Some ruins remain in the area.
Remarks: In 1912, the Santa Fe Railroad laid out a new town named Montezuma which continues to thrive.

Current Status: Some ruins of old stone houses remain.
Remarks: The townsite is now a part of the Hanna Hereford Ranch.

Current Status: Nothing remains of the townsite except for a Santa Fe Trail marker and a cemetery.

Remarks: The town was short-lived but the post office existed decades longer than the actual town.

Current Status: The town was abandoned when Meade Center won the county seat. Nothing remains but a main street through Meade is named Carthage.
Renamed Artesian City from Spring Lake in 1887, nothing remains of the townsite.
The exact location of the first townsite of Veteran is unknown but the second location became Johnson City in 1886.
Remarks: The town of Veteran was apparently founded by Civil War Veterans.

Current Status: The main street and an old schoolhouse remain.
The ruins of a schoolhouse remain in the area.
A cemetery, ruins of an old church and an abandoned stone house are all that remain of the town.
A small population remains along with an old cemetery, schoolhouse and the natural mounds the town was named for.
Muncie is now a part of suburban Kansas City.

Remarks: Zarah might have been located near Shawnee Mission Parkway and Woodland Road.
Was the county seat from 1861 until 1864.

Current Status: A cemetery and some farms are all that remain.
A United Methodist Church is located on K-166 east of Cedarvale.
Little remains of the townsite, a small population remains.

Remarks: The entire town was auctioned off in 1909.

Current Status: A grain elevator and some other buildings remain.
Remarks: Black Wolf is currently on private property.
The last building marking the site burned down in 1967.

Current Status: Little remains of the townsite, a small population remains.
Some houses and ruins remain in the area.
All that remains is an abandoned grain elevator.
Remarks: Founded as Gage until 1901.

Current Status: Structures still stand, and two families still live on the townsite.
Town has been completely vacant for a few years. Six buildings remain standing on the townsite, including an elevator & old school.
Two vacant grain elevators, two vacant houses, an old school, and a few ruins remain in this town.
